ratings.question_text: What percentage of the reading and other assignments did you complete?

narratives.question_text: How well was the course organized?
comments: I thought the course covered as much material as it possible could have, and that the work covered spanned many different styles and types of creator - playwright, playwright who works with company, older playwright, older ensemble, newer ensemble, etc. I found the pairing of works (Young Jean Lee-Richard Maxwell-CLYBOURNE PARK, for example) thought-provoking. The organization of the course generated a lot of interesting discussion.
*Great syllabus, full of relevant writers, and a great course to dive into contemporary concerns on American and UK stages

narratives.question_text: How effective was the balance between instruction and discussion?
comments: The discussions were well moderated and organized by the instructor. The instructor could truly lead a master class in how to balance instruction and discussion.
*Marc is effective at asking questions and guiding conversation and even filling in when students are reluctant to speak (reluctant through no fault of Marc's)
I thought there was a good balance between instruction and discussion. We had really exciting discussions about the plays we read and Marc did a great job getting all students involved.

narratives.question_text: How well did the assigned papers, reports or other projects reflect the aims of the course?
comments: I learned a lot in doing the first smaller paper, and it gave me more confidence going into the longer final paper.

*I think that writing a play review and a end of term paper are great exercises and the right direction to go. *Perhaps the length of the term paper could be shorter to adjust for the fact that another paper came before it in the middle of the term. After all, combined, the length of these two papers would actually equal the usual 15-20 pages one-paper assignment of most courses.

narratives.question_text: How did the amount of assigned reading work with weekly discussion?
comments: There were several weeks when there was a substantial amount of reading. It's hard to classify how much is too much, because play scripts are formatted with such variation, but anytime it got to or around the 250 page range, it was a lot to accomplish in a week and there were times when we gave a quick treatment to some of the assigned reading. That being said, the exposure to so much work far outweighed the inconvenience of reading so much, especially because the reading was so well "curated."

*Sometimes plays were short, which actually allowed for reading three to four of them before class. Other times plays were all lengthy, and so getting them all read before class was at times difficult, especially during other YSD/Rep responsibilities. *Maybe the class needs to reassess the reading load on some days of the syllabus? It's not a matter of complaining that something is too much. It's more a matter of the kind of discussion that one wants to have in class. With less material to cover, more people will be inclined to actually dig into a discussion, especially since they will have been able to balance the reading for the class with their other YSD expectations. *On the other hand, Marc was excellent at not being precious about cramming things into the day's class. If we got to it, we got to it. Otherwise, it had to be let go, which is a very zen attitude to have, and actually helps keep the whole syllabus on track.
The videos were an essential part of the course for me, especially the ones of the Nature Theater of Oklahoma and Forced Entertainment.
*For people dealing with a literary and visual practice, seeing those performance videos was an absolute must.
I thought Marc provided some great supplementary materials that gave a much clearer sense of several of the plays that we read.
It was great to have videos of productions when available.

narratives.question_text: The course filled a significant gap in your knowledge of the field.
comments: I learned about contemporary American and British drama in this course. Even works that I had seen in production were discussed in a way that made me re-consider them.
*Got me aware of what is currently happening in the Anglophone playwriting/production sphere (very much needed in my case)
The dramaturgy department by and large neglects contemporary work, so this course filled a hole.

narratives.question_text: Regardless of whether or not the course is required, would you recommend it to other students in and outside the department?
comments: Yes
This course is great for anyone interested in the material.

*Yes *As a testament to this affirmative answer, I think our class make-up this semester is indicative of why others should take the class. We had stage managers, playwrights, American Studies graduate students, and Divinity graduate students at our table, and our discussions were definitely enriched by the outside department experiences these students brought to the class. *Contemporary Am/Brit theater affects us all in the present, and it is always valuable to know what the current state of drama/theater/performance is, especially when one is going into that field as part of one's professional practice.
Yes, a lot of our courses touch on theatre before the turn of the 20th century, so it's helpful to have a discussion of contemporary work. And the discussion in the class was really thoughtful.
Yes

narratives.question_text: The course goals were clearly presented.
comments: I thought the goal of each paper was outlined very clearly.
I don't remember. Which would lead me to believe they weren't clear... but I'm not sure.

narratives.question_text: The instructor has a strong grasp of the course subject matter.
comments: *Marc knows what he's talking about. *Marc has seen what he's talking about. *Marc writes about what he's talking about. *Marc is EXCELLENT.

narratives.question_text: The instructor presented the subject matter effectively.
comments: *See answer to question 9

comments: Nothing toshow..

comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: The grading criteria was clearly explained.
comments: *I got the feeling that the grading criteria is: GET IT DONE. DO IT WELL. If this was the case, then my rating stands.
I don't recall any discussion of the criteria for grading papers. The instructions were very vague; I would have liked expectations to be more clearly delineated.

narratives.question_text: The instructor was available for consultation, discussion and advice.
comments: A plea for Marc to be more available and responsive. His feedback is invaluable, but sometimes difficult to obtain.
The meeting I had with the instructor to discuss my first paper and the ideas for my second paper was very productive and essential in shaping the purview of my second paper.

*Marc was usually available immediately after class and sporadically through email. He always got back to me, at least. I don't know about my other classmates, though...he is a busy man with many cross appointments after all.

It was sometimes difficult to get in touch with Marc and it often took him a long time to reply to emails asking question or requesting meetings. But when he did respond, it was always thorough and thoughtful.
Getting responses to emails was sometimes difficult.

narratives.question_text: I would recommend this instructor to other students.
comments: *SEE ANSWER TO QUESTION 9

narratives.question_text: How many of the 14 class meetings did you attend?  Comments:
comments: All.
All of them except one which conflicted with a Rep assignment, otherwise I would have been there. I looked forward to this class every week. That is the strength of a relevant syllabus!
All 14 class meetings.
All

narratives.question_text: Please offer additional comments you have on such topics as: what worked best about the course, what improvements you would suggest, etc.
comments: A fabulous course - thank you very much for teaching it.
I very much hope the course continues and continues to be updated in the future!

*Focus the amount of reading around other assignments *Less is more, I have always found *Keep encouraging students to see productions *GREAT that we got to see David Greenspan *Marc has connections, and so does this school. Let's use them. More visual experiences, please, to go along with our written/reading work.
